keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Glória funicular in Lisbon snapped during a journey, leading to a deadly crash that killed at least 16 people and injured several others.
The cable failed to meet specifications set by CARRIS, the funicular's operator, and did not pass certification standards required for passenger use.
Maintenance tasks were improperly documented, with tasks marked as completed even when not actually performed, and the maintenance plan was falsely recorded as compliant.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
Eyewitnesses described the derailment as sudden and chaotic, with one man named Bruno describing the car as 'completely out of control' and noting the sound of screams and a cloud of brown smoke.
A final report on the crash is scheduled for release in 2026, and the interim findings are noted as preliminary and not conclusive.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In September 2025, a fatal crash occurred on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, when a steel cable snapped during operation, resulting in at least 16 deaths and multiple injuries. A preliminary investigation by the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) revealed that the cable failed to meet the safety specifications established by the operator, CARRIS, and that maintenance logs were falsified, with tasks marked as completed without actual execution. Eyewitnesses described the derailment as chaotic and terrifying, with one man named Bruno noting the car's uncontrolled descent and the appearance of smoke. The findings highlight systemic failures in maintenance and safety certification, and while the report is preliminary, it underscores urgent concerns about public transportation safety in historic urban infrastructure.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
